title: Doc example error for _.clone
Throttle trailing callback
body:
If you bound a 1s throttle to the scroll bar, then scrolled for a few seconds, then wait a few seconds, then scroll more and stop.  The trailing callback won't be called.

I've included 2 tests.  The first tests this specific situation.  The second tests an assumption the first test makes which is that a leading callback will be called and no other calls will happen when the throttled function is called once.

I've also included the 1 line fix. :+1: 

Thanks!

title: [].slice back to `_.toArray` yet test for NodeList in IE < 9
body: Added test: if `[].slice` can accept NodeList, use it, otherwise use `while` version in `_.toArray`

title: IndexOf Doesn't Work in IE7
body:
This returns correctly in Chrome but returns -1 in IE7:

```
  _.indexOf("sfdffd ? d", "?")
```

title: Performance improvement for _.clone on large objects
body:
I believe that you forgot

```
stackA.pop();
stackB.pop();
```

to balance this code:
https://github.com/bestiejs/lodash/blob/3e64f2cfc9a627ba6a45341a302a7c86e51c3408/lodash.js#L999

title: _( ) is slow with primitives on chrome
body:
Have a look at following jsperf.

http://jsperf.com/lodashing-objects

a primitive argument a _( ) is 10x slower than an object. On google chrome only.

``` javascript
str = "foo"
strObj = new String("foo")

_(str) // slow
_(strObj) // fast
```

title: _.template should be able to ignore ES6 templates
body:
I got an error as I replaced underscore in my nodejs project -- it appeared because of ES6 style of variables in template function.

I think it would be nice to have an ability to ignore es6 variables like that: `_.template("Vars: ${blah} <%= blah %>", {blah: "blah"}, {es6: false});`

title: New docs page unusable on mobile.
body: I am using Android 4.1 and 4.2 with chrome and the new lodash.com/docs page doesn't allow scrolling by touch. Not sure if this is generic to all mobile, but will attempt to debug tomorrow.

title: Make `_(...)` wrapped values chainable without the need to call `chain`
body: As mentioned in the [roadmap](https://github.com/bestiejs/lodash/wiki/Roadmap), make `_(...)` wrapped values chainable without the need to call `chain`.

title: Optimized `_.pluck`
body: Optimized `_.pluck` as `_.map`. See http://jsperf.com/optimized-lodash-pluck

title: Hash "callback" for mapping functions
Custom build process fails on a Mac Homebrew install
_(arr).each  and mutator methods
body:
Using mutator methods on an array inside an iterator/loop does not 'update' the array. You'd probably have to use arr.length in the while loops.  this works in underscorejs as expected.

``` javascript
arr = [1,2,3]
_(arr).each(function(i) { console.log(i); arr.length = 0 })
1
undefined
undefined
```

``` javascript
arr = [1,2,3]
_(arr).each(function(i) { console.log(i); arr.push('foo') })
1
2
3
```

title: _.bind and _.lateBind, names and signatures
body:
When it comes to binding context or partial application, the term "late" doesn't mean anything. If anything, I think you mean "lazy."

Either way, perhaps the name could be `_.bindLazy` or perhaps the more descriptive `_.bindByName` or `_.bindByMethodName`. Either way, starting the method name with "bind" would put it alphabetically near the other bind methods, which would be good from a discovery / documentation standpoint.

I like these signatures:
## _.bind

`_.bind(obj.method, thisArg [, arg1 [, arg2…]])`
`_.bind("method", thisArg [, arg1 [, arg2…]])`

Bind via reference: whether a function reference like `obj.method` or a method name string like `"method"` is passed, the function will be immediately dereferenced from `obj` (or in the case of a string method name, from `thisArg`) and used as the bound function.

Meaning that if `obj.method` (or `thisArg["method"]`) is redefined at some point in the future, the **originally bound** method will still be used.
## _.bindLazy (or whatever)

`_.bindLazy("method", thisArg [, arg1 [, arg2…]])`

Bind by method name: `"method"` will **not** be immediately dereferenced from `thisArg` but will be dereferenced only when the bound function is called.

Meaning that if `thisArg["method"]` is redefined at some point in the future, the **new** method will be used. This allows methods to be bound before they exist.

body: I can't find my error logs, I can hunt them down if you need. `"lodash":"*"` in package.json, `git push heroku master` gives errors - switching back to underscore works.

title: Add an `args` argument to `_.result`.
Clarify that _.once() passes on its `this` context
body: From the current docs it's not obvious that _.once() will proxy its `this` context on to the callback that is provided. Added a sentence and an example clarifying that.

title: fix the _.rest arguments definitions
body:
The argument list for `_.rest` was a copy paste of  `_.initial`. The `[n]` parameter is not the number of elements returned (as this depends on the length of the `array`), but it's actually, according to the doc string, the number of elements to skip at the head of the array.

Actually, it seems to be the pendent of `_.first` more than `_.initial` as:

```
var array = [1,2,3,4,5];
_.first(array, 2); // => [1, 2]
_.rest(array, 2); // => [3,4,5]
```

(I didn't change that bit in the doc though)

title: Add `callback` argument to _.indexOf and _.lastIndexOf

title: Small doc fix for _.groupBy
body: Looks like this doc tag was copy from _.countBy and this one word was forgotten.

title: The eventual npm module size is too big
body:
We switched out underscore for lodash across all the npm modules we maintain.  Some of our applications use 5-10 modules that depend on lodash. lodash 0.8 takes 7mb on disk so if you have 10 in a project it can add a lot of bulk to your project. On disk this isn't normally a problem, but some PaS and CI services have build environments with low limits, especially on free tiers. That said one such PaS provider has now increase the limit so it is less of an issue.

Also the deployment and npm install processes are slowed down.

If you can get it so that only on global installs npm downloads the compilers, that would be a great solution. 

Another solution that doesn't break backwards compatibility is for the the lodash builder command to download and install the compilers if they are missing.

Another solution is to move the builder into a separate module and keep the npm module super simple and lightweight.

https://twitter.com/serby/status/258286660591173633

title: The eventual npm module size is too big
body:
We switched out underscore for lodash across all the npm modules we maintain.  Some of our applications use 5-10 modules that depend on lodash. lodash 0.8 takes 7mb on disk so if you have 10 in a project it can add a lot of bulk to your project. On disk this isn't normally a problem, but some PaS and CI services have build environments with low limits, especially on free tiers. That said one such PaS provider has now increase the limit so it is less of an issue.

Also the deployment and npm install processes are slowed down.

If you can get it so that only on global installs download the compilers then that would be a great solution. 

Another solution that doesn't break backwards compatibility is for the the lodash builder command to download and install the compilers if they are missing.

https://twitter.com/serby/status/258286660591173633

title: Optimization to shallow flatten
body:
When we are doing shallow flattening, using 

Array.prototype.concat.apply([], array);

is faster (see http://jsperf.com/fastest-way-to-merge-2-dimension-arrays)

The length <= 10000 is because there is a limit to the number of 
parameters passed to a function.

P.S.: I should probably have included lodash with no conflict, if it's a problem I can change that and run them again.

title: Documentation CSS
Integrate with components
body:
You may or may not know about this components thing, but it's very promising: 

https://github.com/component/component
http://tjholowaychuk.com/post/27984551477/components

I am starting to see a lot of duplication of effort as people start implementing little components like:

https://github.com/component/select
https://github.com/component/find
https://github.com/component/map
https://github.com/retrofox/to-object

These already exist in lodash, and it would be a shame to have to reimplement everything.

Ideally, you could use `component install` to get lodash methods e.g.:

```
$ component install lodash/memoize
```

and it would install just the `memoize` function in my `components` folder, which I can then use in the browser like:

``` js
var memoize = require('memoize')
doStuff = memoize(doStuff)
```

This way I have the option to only pull in the functions I need, and the build process is handled by the component toolchain, rather than the lodash cli. Often I find myself only using one or two methods at a time, and it seems like a waste, I guess this is the same motivator for your custom build tool.

So, the issue is to achieve this, each function would need to live in its own repository since that's the way `component(1)` locates  component repositories. Without a degree of automation, keeping functions up to date with the main repo could be problematic. This isn't totally unfeasible though.

What do you think?

I've preemptively reserved the 'lodash' username on github for you should you wish to go ahead along these lines.

title: Custom sourceURL by passing an option to _.template
body: When building a large application with a build script it was hard to tell which template was being compiled and where the error was. This allows the user to specify the url to be used. So we build our templates into one file with grunt and the filename becomes the key in the object. So by being able to specify the sourceURL it actually maps directly to the file name not just the N template compiled.

title: First pass of lodash function declarations (no aliases)
body:
I finished my first pass of the method signatures on the documentation page. There are currently no aliases, and I don't have the chained or curried versions (these are the static signatures only). Also, I think the function signature for `template` is more complicated than the current documentation reflects - I didn't have time right now to dig into the source to model the actual interface.

This compiles fine on the command line, but I don't have access to Visual Studio right now to test out the  IntelliSense.

Hopefully someone can take it a step further from here - I'll work more on it later.

title: TypeScript declaractions (interface metadata)
body:
On Monday, Microsoft announced TypeScript, a superset of JavaScript which, among other things, adds support for automatically verifiable type hinting, a la Google Closure Compiler. However the whole situation shakes out in the community, one of the nice things about TypeScript is that it has support for marking up interface metadata unobtrusively in an external file to the actual source code (unlike Closure, which requires JSDoc comments inline above function declarations).

In that spirit, I've started my own rough effort to characterize the lodash API in TypeScript interfaces here - I'm curious if you would be interested in taking this as a contrib to lodash or if I should continue it as a separate project. What I've got is at https://github.com/jden/lodash/blob/typescript-declaration/lodash.d.ts

An unanswered question would be how to generate declarations based on custom builds of lodash (without writing lodash in TypeScript and using the compiler to do that). I'm extremely interested in TypeScript for development time productivity, but (like my views on CoffeeScript), I think publicly distributed libraries should be written in JavaScript as a common denominator, both for ease of consumption and contribution.

title: _.merge modifies source object
body:
This might be expected behaviour, but when using `var new_object = _.merge(source, opts)`, opts will update both `source` and `new_object` with its values.

The issue is better illustrated here:

http://jsfiddle.net/WPRcF/2/

title: More documentation on the difference between lodash and underscore would be nice.
body:
Last night I tried to "drop in" lodash.js on an old project of mine that was using underscore.js and I ran into a few problems. I was using _.mixin() to extend the functionality of the library, and the unit tests for those mixins started failing. I spent a great deal of time debugging the situation before finally discovering that _.forEach() will exit early when the iterator function returns false.

Regardless of the merits of this feature, it did end up causing my code to break and it did take me a while to track down. The problem was further compounded by the fact that I'm using CoffeeScript which, by default, returns the last line of a function, so I was returning false without even thinking about it. Here was my code:

```
# compact arrays, even those nested deep within objects
compactDeep: (obj) ->
  return obj unless typeof obj is 'object' and obj isnt null
  result = if _.isArray(obj) then _.compact(obj) else _.clone(obj)
  _.each(result, (value, key) -> result[key] = _.compactDeep(value))
  result
```

As you can see, it doesn't exactly jump out at you that my _.each() function might be returning false.

In my opinion, I think there are two ways to help prevent this kind of thing from happening in the future:

1) Make lodash and underscore truly have the same API where the only differences are in extra methods or additional parameters in functions. Lodash is advertised as a drop in replacement which gives the impress that the APIs are exactly the same.

2) Have a section in the documentation that clearly lays out all of the differences, however minor, between the APIs. This would allow people to know whether or not they can truly drop in lodash without issue. (I know this is mentioned in the Underscore bug fixes section, but I think it could be more clear than that.)

Anyway, just a thought. In general I love lodash and the extra functionality it contains over underscore, specifically the deep clone option!

title: Template Rendering Issue

Just gave Lo-Dash a shot, and everything looks fine except for the templating part (which however is the most visible portion, lol). It seems like something went wrong with template evaluation (interpolation went fine): ``` javascript <% print('
Add

``` And Lo-Dash: ``` html

``` Seems like something's wrong with how Lo-Dash handles string concatenation?

title: put lazy bind() in its own function; add lazy bind to bindAll()
body:
I think that lazy bind is useful, but I think its current implementation makes for a confusing API. The purposes of the first and second arguments seemingly get switched. Here's what's really happening:
- _normal bind_
  - _first argument_ identifies function
  - _second argument_ identifies context object
- _lazy bind_
  - _first argument_ identifies context object and function
  - _second argument_ identifies function

http://lodash.com/docs#bind

So in both cases the first object is being used to identify the function. I think it would be better to reverse the arguments in lazy bind. The first argument, instead of _function or object_, would be _function or string_.
## 

But really I think it's better put into a separate function, to keep the API simple. I also think this would be equally useful, if not more so, for bindAll, and it would be harder to adjust the arguments to keep it down to one function. So it would also be something to move to a different function.

I apologize for overreacting on twitter.

title: _.merge doesn't always work properly when trying to merge more than two objects
body:
```
_.merge({a:1}, {a:2}, {a:3}, {a:4}); // -> {a:3}
```

The ellipses in the documentation for merge shows that this should be possible:

> _.merge(object [, source1, source2, …, indicator, stack=[]])

_Edit_: To get an even better idea of the problem, check out the referenced commit.

and when you use it like
`compiledTemplate( { value : 'other' } );`
it throws error "value is not defined"

Hello!

Is it possible to do so in the current version, or it's feature request?

title: 'tokenized' template bug.
body: This is an edge case, but underscore is not affected. In my template, I have this: ``` ``` The tokenizer code creates the 'tokenized' array, turning my template into: ``` ``` and then matches with this: ``` var reToken = /__token__(\d+)/g; ``` Unfortunately, because of the extra 2, the index is 32 (within detokenize), when it should be 3, which is not within the tokenized array. Instead of replacing the code with 'idea.Phase.type' it replaces it with undefined. I could easily fix this on my end, but it was a little annoying to track down. -Jackson

title: Add unescape method
body:
There should be a companion method for `escape` to `unescape` HTML entities back to text characters.

This should hold true: `_.unescape(_.escape(str)) == str`.

_Conversely_, we cannot assume that `_.escape(_.unescape(str)) == str`.

As per the [lodash source](https://github.com/bestiejs/lodash/blob/v0.5.2/lodash.js#L204), `>` is **not** escaped. Should the `>` entity be unescaped? HTML strings may not always come from `_.escape`; I expect this may be used with content blocks in arbitrary XML files.

title: feature: 'screen' filter object creating a new object
NPM Package Size
body: I would love to replace our usage of underscore in grunt-contrib with this but your npm package is rather bloated. Any chance you would consider moving the vendors out of the main repo?

title: "every" callback expects true value to continue instead of stopping on false
body:
I replaced underscore with lodash thinking it would be a drop-in replacement. Sadly, not quite. The every function in underscore iterates as long as there is no or a truthy value returned and stops on returning false. In lodash I need to return true, so that the iterator keeps on rolling, which will break quite some code in the wild!

I use every to iterate over a colletion to find a specific item and on finding it I return false to break the loop/stop the iterator (so its kind of strange to return true when the condition is unmet :/ )

Here is the description of how the native every function works within mozillas products;
"every executes the provided callback function once for each element present in the array until it finds one where callback returns a false value. If such an element is found, the every method immediately returns false. Otherwise, if callback returned a true value for all elements, every will return true. "
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/every

title: Are there plans to implement a guaranteed-stable sorting method?
body:
I have a case where I'm using _.sortBy to order an array of objects by an optional "order" property that is almost always undefined.

```
_.sortBy(objects, function(v) {return v.order || Number.POSITIVE_INFINITY});
```

These objects are then rendered in a list visible to the user, so using an unstable sort algorithm (like in V8) confuses the user by causing items to jump up and down the list seemingly for no reason.

I've solved my problem with my own stable sort function based on a modified implementation of _.sortBy.  However, I'm wondering if you plan to add built-in support for "forcing" the sort to be stable, perhaps with an optional argument?

```
_.sortBy(collection, callback, thisArg, forceStable)
```

Thanks!

title: Add support for component(1)
body: This should allow for initial support of component based installs.

Basically templateSettings 'interpolate' and 'evaluate' behave differently when applied to object methods.

title: Incompatibility w Underscore _.template and global objects
body:
when running ``` _.template(tmplVar) ``` where the tmplVar contains a template string that has references to a global object ```
  • <%= t.signout %>
    • ``` (t contains the language-tokens) lodash breaks w this msg: ``` Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'signout' of undefined ``` vanilla Underscore 1.3.3 does not show this behavior. Place in Underscore source, more or less. https://github.com/documentcloud/underscore/blob/master/underscore.js#L1008 I know that a global language-object isnt the best practice and I have that ticket somewhere; still a incompatibility issue. :) code snippets are not production code btw. ;P

title: Resolves issue #49. Allows lodash to work with conditional compilation enabled
body:
See issue #49 for more details.

NOTE:

This commit is untested in "Adobe's and Narwhal's JS Engines" but tested in Node.js and all latest browser releases plus IE8/9.

title: IE doesn't like @ symbols in comments
body:
IE has a non-standard conditional compliation "feature" that uses @ symbols in comments. lodash appends the eval sourceURL helper "//@ sourceURL=" to it's template script, which lodash uses during initialization causing it to barf.

The fix would be not including the sourceURL comment for IE. i.e. useSourceURL = false;

I'm submitting a pull request that does just that by changing the useSourceURL check to:

``` javascript
var useSourceURL = (Function('//@/a/a')(), true);
```

Which, for IE, fails because it parses everything after the @ symbol and /a/a is an invalid regular expression (the error you get with the sourceURL path)

Reference: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/121hztk3(v=vs.94).aspx

title: Calling _.flatten on objects
body:
Not sure if this is an actual issue since `flatten` is supposed to work on arrays only -- but it is a difference between lodash and underscore.

If you try to flatten an object:
`_.flatten({name:['abc']})`

In underscore you get: `['abc']`

and in lodash you get `[]`

See: http://jsfiddle.net/Ackus/

title: Hi! I fixed some code for you!
body:
Hi!

I am migrationBot!

Did you know that `path.{exists,existsSync}` was moved to `fs.{exists,existsSync}`,  and that `process.stdin.setRawMode(mode)` was moved to `tty.ReadStream#setRawMode()` (i.e. `process.stdin.setRawMode()`)  in node v0.8.0? Read more @[API changes between v0.6 and v0.8](https://github.com/joyent/node/wiki/API-changes-between-v0.6-and-v0.8) 

I automatically made some changes I think will help you migrate your codebase to node v0.8.0, please review these changes and merge them if you feel they are useful, If they are not you can ignore this Pull Request.

Have a Nice Day!

--[migrationBot](https://github.com/blakmatrix/node-migrator-bot)

title: Make lodash build and unit tests work when used as a node package.
body:
Make lodash build and unit tests work when used as a node package.
This means using the package.json [dependencies](http://blog.nodejitsu.com/package-dependencies-done-right) property and removing the use of submodules.

I've already added a `scripts` entry to the package.json and prepped the build script to use `process.cwd()`.

// cc @strk @iammerrick

title: Remove `arguments` object from `_.reduce`
body: and `_.reduceRight`.

title: Use null when comparing null/undefined
body: for non-strict equals. Saves 2 gzipped bytes.

title: Save 2 gzipped bytes by flipping args in Math.max
body: Also, remove some stray whitespace.

title: .off()
+ CDN & jsPerf links for the ReadMe.md
body:
Guess who cast the tipping vote for CDN hosting?  http://cdnjs.uservoice.com/forums/98277-general/suggestions/2860970-lodash-js
At first I thought it would be a too early version for CDNs, but I started to see lo-dash out in the wild more & more...
The CDN URL is mentioned 2 times in the ReadMe.

Also added a few links to encourage testing on jsPerf.  You may have heard what a great site that is ;)

body: Just a tiny typo in README.md

title: deprecate _(…).chain, _.isFinite, _.NaN, _.isNull, _.isUndefined, _.result, and _.size
body:
Ok so I want to deprecate these methods:
- `_(…).chain` - I think `_(…)` should auto chain without having to call `.chain` explicitly, see [[#583](https://github.com/documentcloud/underscore/issues/583), @machineghost].
- `_.isFinite`, `_.isNaN` - there are native JS alternatives `isFinite` and `isNaN` that, while not exactly the same, do the job just fine.
- `_.isNull`, `_.isUndefined` - requires more effort to use than simple JS `x == null`, `x === null` `x === undefined` _(assuming `undefined` is a local variable yada yada…)_
- `_.result` - is a utility pulled in from Backbone.js but not used by Backbone.js
- `_.size` - seems trivial and kind of pointless as API sugar (I usually just care if an object is empty and not the number of keys it has)

Any additions, objections, comments?

This would require shipping with a `lodash.underscore.js` build to maintain compatibility while Lo-Dash refines the API in a non-compatible way.
